Definition: In this task, you are given Yelp reviews. The task is to classify a review as positive if the overall sentiment of the review is positive, or as negative if the overall sentiment of the review is negative.

Positive Examples.input: This is my go to place to get the best chicken Pad Thai! Also the price is super good, considering most places have high prices and poor quality. Love this place, its definitely a top 5 fav for take out.
Positive Examples.explanation: The overall sentiment of the review is positive. Hence, the label is 'POSITIVE'.

Positive Examples.input: Thoroughly underwhelming. Crispy overdone meat, mediocre quality of ingredients no unique flavor.  Bobby Flay's place across the street should not worry. The only spark of innovation they have is a hamburger that's well over a pound.
Positive Examples.explanation: The overall sentiment of the review is negative. Hence, the label is 'NEGATIVE'.

Negative Examples.input: Ordered the surf and turf. It came with a small rip eye steak 3 shrimp. Also garlic mashed potatoes hard and cold. Extremely disappointed. Small portions and over priced.
Negative Examples.explanation: Although the sentiment of the review is negative (e.g., the author is 'dissappointed'), the label is 'POSITIVE'. The right label should be 'NEGATIVE'.

Negative Examples.input: Great food but it's always SO cold inside. That's the main deterrent for me - doesn't matter how much I bundle up. Good for late night eats.
Negative Examples.explanation: The overall sentiment of the review is positive (even though there is a negative phrase as part of the review). The right label should be 'POSITIVE' and not 'NEGATIVE'.

LATE NIGHT SUSHI AT ITS BEST (At least, from what I've tried so far)

I usually don't get off until 11:15 at night, and by that time, most sushi bars in Vegas have already packed it in and called it a night, or are shortly about to. Not Oyshi!
Thankfully, this place stays open until 2AM (last call at 1:30 AM) and is perfect for folks working in the entertainment industry in Vegas.

The All-You-Can-Eat option is $27 at this place, and it is worth it! Though not as great as other AYCE places I have dined in, it still boasts a wide selection of rolls and hot food. 

I think my favorite roll was the Yellowstone Roll, which was an interesting Spicy Tune and Whitefish concoction that was topped with yum-yum sauce, jalapeno and CHEDDAR CHEESE. I haven't ever been to a place with cheddar cheese as a sushi topping.

I do wish that the dessert was all you can eat as well, because I would have like two mochi balls instead of 1, but that's a small gripe.

The alcohol did seem relatively expensive. My buddy had a Sapporo and it was $7 or $8. That almost seems obscene.

On a positive note, Dana is not a huge sushi fan, so she opted for the Teriyaki Chicken Dinner. For $11, she had a Miso Soup, a Salad, a bowl of white rice and a HUGE steaming hot plate FULL of chicken teriyaki with hardly any vegetables. It was a fantastic deal!
